block.p: Military Files Contradict Marine Accounts of Raid A military investigator uncovered evidence in February and March that contradicted repeated assertions by marines that Iraqi civilians killed in Haditha last November had been the victims of a roadside bomb, according to a senior military official.

War Not the Only Killer in Darfur While the war in Darfur, Sudan, has set off what the United Nations has called the ''world's worst humanitarian crisis,'' these days most people in the region die not from bullets, but because they cannot get health care, clean water or enough food.

Europe Court Rejects Air Pact The European Union's highest court ruled that the European Union had overstepped its authority by agreeing to give the United States personal details about airline passengers on flights to America in an effort to fight terrorism.

Quake Victims Waiting for Aid Three days after a powerful earthquake rocked Indonesia, killing roughly 5,700 people, many devastated villages within the two worst-hit districts had yet to receive any help, residents said.

Somali Gunmen Seize Hospital Discarding the neutrality of hospitals in Somalia's long civil conflict, gunmen allied with a warlord linked to the United States seized control of a medical facility in Mogadishu, causing many wounded patients to flee and reducing medical services to a minimum.

For Support, U.S. Shifts on Iran The Bush administration, seeking to enlist Russian support for a United Nations Security Council resolution on Iran, has agreed to language ruling out the immediate threat of military force against Iran, American and European officials said.

Officials Sternly Advise Hurricane Preparations Officials in hurricane-prone states are trumpeting dire warnings about the coming storm season, preaching self-reliance and prodding the public to prepare early and well.
A Message for Tougher Borders Advocates of tougher border security have sent thousands of bricks to Senate and House offices to emphasize the benefits of a fence along the border with Mexico.

Setback for Whistle-Blowers The Supreme Court ruled that the Constitution does not protect public employees against retaliation by their supervisors for anything they say in the course of performing their assigned duties.
F.B.I. Calls Off Search for Hoffa The F.B.I. called off its search for the remains of James R. Hoffa, saying it found no trace of him on a horse farm in Michigan.
Sniper Guilty in 2nd Trial John A. Muhammad, the sniper who terrorized the Washington, D.C., area in 2002, was found guilty on six counts of first-degree murder in Maryland.

Surveys Shed Light on H.I.V. New surveys suggest that the global AIDS epidemic has begun to slow, with a decline in new H.I.V. infections in about 10 countries, the head of the United Nations AIDS program said in a report.

Global Warming and Hurricanes Climate researchers at Purdue University and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology reported new evidence supporting the idea that global warming is causing more destructive hurricanes.

Spitzer Handily Wins Backing for Governor Eliot Spitzer overwhelmingly won the backing of the New York State Democratic Party for his campaign for governor. He pledged to confront ''the crisis of leadership'' in Albany with the same zeal he used to pursue Wall Street executives as the state's aggressive attorney general.

Friend Testifies in Bias Trial Frankie Agostini, a childhood friend of Nicholas Minucci, a white man accused of a bias attack against a black man in Queens, testified during Mr. Minucci's trial that the defendant repeatedly used a racial epithet before, during and after the attack.

Librarians Break Silence Four Connecticut librarians who were barred from revealing that they had received a request for patrons' records from the federal government finally spoke out, expressing frustration about the sweeping powers given to law enforcement authorities in what is known as the U.S.A. Patriot Act.

Hugh B. Patterson Jr. The publisher of The Arkansas Gazette in 1957 when the paper was thrust into national prominence for its stand against segregated schools during a federal-state confrontation, he was 91.
Shohei Imamura One of the most significant filmmakers of Japan's postwar generation, whose works include ''Black Rain'' and two top-prize winners at Cannes, he was 79.

New Treasury Secretary President Bush has chosen Henry M. Paulson Jr. of Goldman Sachs as his next Treasury secretary, a move intended to add economic star power as his administration tries to fight its way through political difficulties.
The nominee has strong views on economic policy that support balanced budgets that may not be consistent with Bush administration policies that have resulted in historic budget deficits.
Markets Fall Once Again As a result of worries about inflation and another rise in interest rates, there was a sell-off on Wall Street: the Dow Jones industrial average dropped 184.18 points.
Editorials: Iran wants to talk; a secretary for troubling times; blow the whistle, loudly; ringside with Caesar's wife.
Columns: Thomas L. Friedman, Maureen Dowd.
